In UnNetHack, Durin's Bane is found in the [Ruins of Moria](/wiki/Ruins_of_Moria "Ruins of Moria") branch, where it will always await the player on the second level, "The Bridge of Khazad-dûm". It carries a [wand of speed monster](/wiki/Wand_of_speed_monster "Wand of speed monster"), a [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") [potion of paralysis](/wiki/Potion_of_paralysis "Potion of paralysis"), and an [enchanted](/wiki/Enchantment "Enchantment") [fireproof](/wiki/Fireproof "Fireproof") [bullwhip](/wiki/Bullwhip "Bullwhip"); it also has a 33% chance of generating with a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection").

### Strategy

Durin's Bane has attributes almost identical to those of an ordinary balrog, but it is faster and better equipped. Like other hostile monsters, it will use its bullwhip to disarm you.

### Encyclopedia entry

... It came to the edge of the fire and the light faded as  
if a cloud had bent over it. Then with a rush it leaped  
the fissure. The flames roared up to greet it, and wreathed  
about it; and a black smoke swirled in the air. Its streaming  
mane kindled, and blazed behind it. In its right hand  
was a blade like a stabbing tongue of fire; in its left it  
held a whip of many thongs.  
'Ai, ai!' wailed Legolas. 'A Balrog! A Balrog is come!'

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

In dNetHack, **Durin's Bane** is the [quest nemesis](/wiki/Quest_nemesis "Quest nemesis") of the dwarf [noble](/wiki/Noble "Noble") quest (Dnb). Unlike many quest nemeses in dNetHack, it is not [covetous](/wiki/Covetous "Covetous") and therefore does not warp to the upstair. Durin's Bane is always equipped with a cursed +9 whip, a potion of speed, and a potion of paralysis. It also has triple the HP of most monsters of its level, so expect the battle to drag on for some time.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Durin's Bane](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search/Durin%27s_Bane "wikipedia:Special:Search/Durin's Bane")***

Durin's Bane is a [balrog](/wiki/Balrog "Balrog") that appears in [J.R.R. Tolkien](/wiki/J.R.R._Tolkien "J.R.R. Tolkien")'s *The Fellowship of the Ring*, where it attacks the Fellowship as they try to pass through the halls of Moria. It is the only balrog seen and described in *Lord of the Rings* (though balrogs also figure in some of Tolkien's other writings, such as the *Silmarillion*) and serves as the model for balrogs in other media, including *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*: the passage describing the encounter with Durin's Bane is used as the encyclopedia entry for "balrog" in vanilla. This is retained even in variants that add Durin's Bane, who is naturally a stronger version of vanilla's standard balrog; the balrog in turn is one of the strongest non-unique [major demons](/wiki/Major_demon "Major demon") in the game.

Durin's Bane is described in *The Fellowship of the Ring* as a vast shadowy creature with a humanoid shape and spreading "wings" - Whether these wings are physical or merely a description of its shadow is [up for debate](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balrog#Characteristics "wikipedia:Balrog"). It wields a blazing sword in one hand and a burning whip in the other - the *NetHack* analogues to this are the [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword") and [bullwhip](/wiki/Bullwhip "Bullwhip") that every balrog starts with.

The balrog that came to be known as "Durin's Bane" was a servant of the evil Morgoth. After Morgoth's defeat, the balrog concealed itself under the Misty Mountains, until it was disturbed or awakened by dwarves mining in their stronghold of Khazad-dûm (Moria). The dwarves gave the balrog its name after it killed their leader Durin VI in battle, which forced them to vacate Moria; the balrog remained in the complex after it was occupied by Sauron's [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)") and [trolls](/wiki/Troll_\(monster_class\) "Troll (monster class)"), and joined the occupying force in trying to kill the Fellowship of the Ring when they attempted to pass through Moria. Durin's Bane proved a powerful foe - it was only defeated after a grueling fight to the death with Gandalf the Grey.

This is retained even in variants that add Durin's Bane, who is naturally a stronger version of vanilla's standard balrog; the balrog in turn is one of the strongest non-unique [[major demon]]s in the game.

Durin's Bane is described in ''The Fellowship of the Ring'' as a vast shadowy creature with a humanoid shape and spreading "wings" - Whether these wings are physical or merely a description of its shadow is [[wikipedia:Balrog#Characteristics|up for debate]]. It wields a blazing sword in one hand and a burning whip in the other - the ''NetHack'' analogues to this are the [[broadsword]] and [[bullwhip]] that every balrog starts with.

The balrog that came to be known as "Durin's Bane" was a servant of the evil Morgoth. After Morgoth's defeat, the balrog concealed itself under the Misty Mountains, until it was disturbed or awakened by dwarves mining in their stronghold of Khazad-dûm (Moria). The dwarves gave the balrog its name after it killed their leader Durin VI in battle, which forced them to vacate Moria; the balrog remained in the complex after it was occupied by Sauron's [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]] and [[Troll (monster class)|trolls]], and joined the occupying force in trying to kill the Fellowship of the Ring when they attempted to pass through Moria. Durin's Bane proved a powerful foe - it was only defeated after a grueling fight to the death with Gandalf the Grey.
